Name: 2passtools
Description: A package for filtering splice junctions extracted from noisy long read alignments generated using minimap2.
Underlying_algorithms: Uses junction alignment metrics and logistic regression on splice junction sequences to classify splice junctions as genuine or spurious
Underlying_assumptions: Assumes a canonical intron motif of GT/AG or GC/AG by default (although this can be changed using CLI options)
Strengths_weaknesses: The filtered spliced junctions can be used to perform second pass alignment with minimap2, feeding in the junctions using the --junc-bed flag.
Overall_performance: For simulated nanopore direct RNA sequencing reads, two pass alignment increased the percentage of correctly aligned spliced reads by >15% for Arabidopsis samples and >20% for human samples

Publications.Title: Two-pass alignment using machine-learning-filtered splice junctions increases the accuracy of intron detection in long-read RNA sequencing

Name: DraftPolisher
Description:
DraftPolisher is a tool for fast polishing of draft sequences. DraftPolisher can produce an improved consensus sequence for a draft genome assembly (or any draft sequence assembly) by using a reference genome and a reference database of sequences (by which the frequences of a defined k-mer, representative of each mismatch, will be evaluated) both in FASTA format.
DraftPolisher is designed for the polishing of draft sequences. Two different releases of the tool are present: DraftPolisher.py and DraftPolisher_cov.py. The "cov" release (i.e. coverage release) takes into account also the coverage of the sequences from the reference database used for the polishing. The "cov" release was designed based on the SPAdes assembling output file format, where the coverage value is reported in the last part of the sequences IDs, so if using this version of the tool take care of the reference sequences file format (see SPAdes output format for more details).Three files are required by the tool: the query sequence to polish, a reference sequence, a reference database of sequences and the size of the k-mer to use to perform the polishing (we suggest k-mer size = 8). In "Test" folder data for testing the tool are available.
Underlying_algorithms: The tool performs a first alignment against a reference sequence (e.g. reference genome) and identify all the missmatches. After, each of the missmatches is evaluated considering a reference database of high quality sequences ( provided by the user). These could be whatever sequences in fasta format. The polishing of the draft sequence is performed considering the frequency of kmers of defined size (default is 16 bp) around each of the missmatches. if the frequency for the mismatches and the reference sequence is the same the missmach is kept, for a conservative approach.
Underlying_assumptions: The reference database of sequences provided, is assumed to be in average a good representation of the correct sequences. This tool is ment for short gaps or mismatches. The tool was designed to use SPAdes tool assembling output as reference database of sequences but can be easly adapted for other sequence database formats.
Strengths_weaknesses: The tool is very fast using MinION data but cannot be used with fastq files (only fasta)
Overall_performance: For MinION assembling data the tool requires few minutes to generate a better quality assembly

Name: Elloreas
Description: Elongating long read assembler
Underlying_algorithms:
1) You provide it with a starter. It can be a contig from some other assembly or just a random read.
2) It maps reads to the 3' end of the starter.
3) It calculates a consensus of reads that overhang the 3' end and extends the starter.
4) It goes to the step "2)".
Strengths_weaknesses: A useful feature of Elloreas is that if it sees several alternative extensions for the contig, it will tell the user about their existence and give their sequences too.
Overall_performance: Created for assembly the mitochondrial genome of Fagopyrum esculentum

A strenght with isONcorrect is that it is designed to leverage from shader exons between different isoforms, increasing the effective coverage for correction.
Underlying_assumptions: Assumes reads are clustered into genes with a clustering algorithm such as isONclust or CARNAC-LR.

Long reads are subsequently anchored to the graph using exact and inexact k-mer matches to find paths corresponding to corrected sequences.

Name: Rebaler
Description: A reference-based assemblies using long reads
Underlying_algorithms: minimap2 for alignment and Racon for consensus sequence generation
Strengths_weaknesses: Reasons to use Rebaler: You want to reassemble/polish an assembly with long reads, using a reference assembly to guide the large-scale structure; You don't want the reference assembly's basecalls to influence the basecalls in your new assembly. Reasons to not use Rebaler: You expect there to be structural differences between your reference genome and your sequenced reads. Rebaler is built on the assumption that the genome structure is the same, only bases differ; You want to polish an assembly using the same long reads you used to make the assembly. Rebaler might work for this, but simply using Racon on its own is probably better

Name: rMETL
Description: A realignment-based Mobile Element insertion detection Tool for Long read
Underlying_algorithms: 1. rMETL extracts the chimerically aligned parts of the reads which have split alignment, large clippings and/or large indels; 2. rMETL clusters the chimerically aligned read parts in predefined rules to infer a set of putative MEI sites as candidates; 3. rMETL realigns the clustered read parts to the consensus sequences of Alu, L1 and SVA families with a well-tuned aligner; 4. rMETL investigates the realignment results to find out the evidence to call MEIs as well as filter false positive candidates.
Strengths_weaknesses: rMETL has good ability to detect MEIs but might fail at the incorrect realignment of read parts or the lack of supporting reads.
Overall_performance: Benchmarking results of simulated and real datasets demonstrate that rMETL enables to handle the complex signals to discover MEIs sensitively. It is suited to produce high-quality MEI callsets in many genomics studies.

Publications.Title: rMETL: sensitive mobile element insertion detection with long read realignment
